title: A history of events in the Cienega Watershed

events.title: Archaeological Testing at the Hummel Property prehistoric component.

events.description: Flat roof, four-room house with central hallway (zaguan) constructed of hand-cast adobe blocks between 1871 and 1874 by William Wakefield.

events.source (original): Heart of the Empire by Laura Soulliere Harrison and Paul J. Neidinger, National Park Service, 1992

events.title: Transfer Reductions'  Policy -- Recommend Elimination
events.description: The management of the Coronado National Forest Reserve began with an emphasis on reducing the stocking rate and a policy of 'transfer reductions' requiring a 10% reduction in permitted numbers each time a permit was reissued. The policy was effective and resulted in removal of hundreds of cattle from Coronado. By the early 1950s, many ranges were no longer overstocked and the policy was rescinded (Allen 1989).

events.title: Major earthquake centered in Batipeto Sonora.
events.description: Earthquake & aftershocks felt from Phoenix to Puerto Vallarta, Mexico and from Yuma to Santa Fe, NM; May & Nov. Estimated seismic level on Richter Scale between 7.2 and 7.4. Largest known earthquake in Arizona. Event changed underground water flows and many springs. Initiated major fires in all Southeast Arizona mountain ranges from falling rocks. Chimneys at Empire ranch collapsed.

events.title: Multiple rain events cause significant flooding damage and erosion in washes and riverbeds
events.description: Droughts, floods, severe overgrazing are major causes of arroyo formation, water channel deepening, and decline of water table throughout SE AZ

events.title: December 15, 1880 the Southern Pacific Railroad is connected with the Santa Fe Railroad at Deming, NM. Train eliminates most stage lines including Nat Mail & T Co., ; no need for Mtn Springs as a stage station.
events.description: By April 1880, Southern Pacific Railroad tracks make it to Punta de Agua where the Pantano Wash and Cienega Creek meet along the old wagon rd.  Railroad is constructed as a levee in the broad floodplain of Cienega. Vail's Siding was built on the last stretch of that land before the railroad tracks entered Cienega Creek.

events.title: Antiquities Act passed,, valid and in use
events.description: Antiquities Act preserves prehistoric, historic & scientifically significant sites, creates national monuments;  (Pub.L. 59‰ÛÒ209, 34 Stat. 225, 16 U.S.C. å¤ 431‰ÛÒ433), signed into law by T Roosevelt. This law gives the President the authority to, by presidential proclamation, create national monuments from public lands to protect significant natural, cultural or scientific features. The Act has been used over a hundred times since its passage, sometimes  controversial.

events.title: Gulf American Corporation purchases Empire Ranch from Pancho Boice for residential development.
events.description: GAC planned to develop a community for over 180,000 residents that spanned the area from the Empire Ranch south to the town of Sonoita. Pima County refused to approve the proposal which threatened water supplies for communities downstream. During the interim, the Boice family continued to reside at ranch and continue grazing cattle under a lease agreement.

events.title: San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio transferred from headwaters of San Pedro River to Fairbanks.
events.description: Location of San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio was unhealthy due to bad climate, bad water and lack of farmland. Presidio moved north to site near Fairbanks on San Pedro River in 1775 and renamed Santa Cruz de Terranate. Again poor choice of location left troops open to Apache attack. Presidio moved again in 1780.
events.source: Wilson JP   . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995.

events.title: Mesquite encroachment out of washes and onto grasslands accelerates
events.description: At the beginning of the 1900s, mesquite was largely confined to large washes above 1000m though early botanists noted small plants within grasslands. Since 1930 mesquite cover and density have rapidly increased. This loss of available grass for grazing led to many different efforts by ranchers to physically remove or chemically poison individual mesquite plants.
events.source (original): McClaren, M. "A Century of Vegetation Change on the Santa Rita Experimental Range." in Santa Rita Experimental Range: 100 Years (1903 to 2003) of Accomplishments and Contributions. Conference Proceedings. USDA Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station. RMRS-P-30.

events.title: Cochise and Chiricahua Apaches initiate 11-year conflict with Anglo Americans
events.description: Second Lieutenant George Bascom from Fort Buchanan confronted Chiricahua Apache chief Cochise at Apache Pass falsely accused of abducting a young Mexican boy from a ranch near Sonoita. Both sides took prisoners, including relatives of Cochise, and killed them. Cochise began a campaign to eliminate all settlers from Southeast Arizona that lasted until the establishment of the Chiricahua Apache reservation in 1872 in the Sulpher Springs Valley.
events.source: Wilson JP   . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995.

events.title: Chiricahua Apache Reservation established
events.description: Chiricahua Apache Reservation established.  First interlude of peace in more than 40 years.Boundaries include San Simon Valley south of Gila River to Mexico border and Dragoon Range to New Mexico border. Reservation cancelled in 1876. Land returned to public domain and Apaches removed to San Carlos reservation. Many renew raiding patterns.

events.description: General Crook ordered Fort Lowell to be moved from downtown Tucson to northeastern corner of Tucson basin. The shift in location brought the military encampment closer to center of Chiricahua Apache operations. The post was closed in 1891.

events.title: Fort Huachuca established.
events.description: Fort Huachuca established in 1877 as one of the military encampments to aid in control of and prevention of depradations by the Chiricahua Apaches after their reservation had been terminated. The fort's establishment coincided with some of the worst conflicts with a small group of Apaches who refused to stay at the San Carlos reservation and instead escaped to follow Naiche and Geronimo. the site was chosen to have quick access to the border region.
events.source: Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.description: By the early 1940s, The Soil Conservation Service (SCS) realized natural resources information was required to develop programs and set priorities for various conservation needs throughout the country. events.title: Environmental Quality Incentives Program
events.description: The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) provides a steady and major source of annual support since 1997. In 1997, NRCS was authorized to provide $2 million throughout Arizona through EQIP and it was gradually increased to $10 million in 2002 and reached $20 million in 2006. A total of 177.5 million dollars was invested from 1997 through 2012. Most of the EQIP money was spent for water development, drought fund, and planning, implement of conservation practices. It‰Ûªs a great help to maintain and improve rangeland conditions, especially to alleviate the drought damage brought by the continues warming and drying climate starting the late 1990s.

Farm Bill
events.description: In the United States, the farm bill is the primary agricultural and food policy tool of the federal government. The comprehensive omnibus bill is passed every 5 years or so by the United States Congress and deals with both agriculture and all other affairs under the purview of the United States Department of Agriculture. The farm bill was first created during the Great Depression to give financial assistance to farmers who were struggling due to an excess crop supply creating low prices, and also to control and ensure an adequate food supply. The first farm bill, known as the Agriculture Adjustment Act (AAA), was passed by Congress in 1933 as a part of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal. The bill allowed farmers to receive payment for not growing food on a percentage of their land as allocated by the United States Secretary of Agriculture. It also enabled the government to buy excess grain from farmers, which could then be sold later if bad weather or other circumstances negatively affected output. The AAA also included a nutrition program, the precursor to food stamps.

events.title: Soil Conservation Service establishes.
events.description: The agency was founded largely through the efforts of Hugh Hammond Bennett, a soil conservation pioneer who had worked for the Department of Agriculture from 1903 to 1952. Bennett's motivation was based on his knowledge of the detrimental effects of soil erosion and the impacts on U.S lands that led to the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. On September 13, 1933, the Soil Erosion Service was formed in the Department of the Interior, with Bennett as chief. The service was transferred to the Department of Agriculture on March 23, 1935, and was shortly thereafter combined with other USDA units to form the Soil Conservation Service by the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1935. Hugh Bennett continued as chief, a position he held until his retirement in 1952. On October 20, 1994, the agency was renamed to the Natural Resources Conservation Service as part of the Federal Crop Insurance Reform and Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994.

events.title: Taylor Grazing Act passed to regulate access for grazing on public lands
events.description: Taylor Grazing Act of 1934 authorized grazing districts and regulations on public lands. (Pub.L. 73‰ÛÒ482) (excluding Alaska) to improve rangeland conditions and regulate their use; administered by the Department of the Interior. As amended, the law applies to approximately 162,000,000 ac  inside grazing allotments. These can be vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved land from public lands, all except for Alaska, national forests, parks, monuments, Indian reservations, railroad grant lands, etc.  Permits are given for grazing privileges in the districts.; or to build fences, reservoirs, and other improvements.  Permittees are required to pay a fee; permit cannot exceed ten years but is renewable. Permits can be revoked because of severe drought or other natural disasters that deplete grazing lands..
events.source: Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988.

events.title: The Arizona surface water code was enacted
events.description: Early in its history, Arizona adopted the doctrine of prior appropriation to govern the use of surface water. This doctrine is based on the tenet of ‰ÛÏfirst in time, first in right‰Û which means that the person who first puts the water to a beneficial use acquires a right that is better than later appropriators of the water.Prior to June 12, 1919, a person could acquire a surface water right simply by applying the water to a beneficial use and posting a notice of the appropriation at the point of diversion. On June 12, 1919, the Arizona surface water code was enacted.  Now known as the Public Water Code, this law provides that a person must apply for and obtain a permit in order to appropriate surface water unless: 1. The water is from the mainstream of the lower Colorado river, in which case a contract with the Secretary of the Interior is required. 2.The person or the person‰Ûªs predecessor-in-interest, lawfully appropriated the water prior to June 12, 1919 and the person or the person‰Ûªs predecessor-in-interest has filed a statement of claim for the appropriation with the state. 3.The water is stored in a stock pond constructed after June 12, 1919 and before August 27, 1977.

The Civilian Conservation Corps efforts in Southern Arizona.
events.description: The Southwest's first Civilian Conservation Corps constructed hundreds of miles of drift fences and numerous water developments on the Coronado during the 1920s and 1930s.Allotments with relatively light stocking rates showed marked improvement. However, the goal of these water developments and fencing were on increasing range capacity and separating animals.  Yet little attention was given to the basic principles of range management such as improving livestock distribution through fencing or rotational grazing (Allen, 1989).  This resulted in heavy use in new areas and brought significant forage competition with resident wildlife.

events.title: The Mexican period brings decentralized political and economic activity on the northern frontier and increased violence on Apaches.
events.description: The Mexican period brings a sharp drop in levels of national (centralized) political and economic activity on the northern frontier; weaker than Spanish national control. Local politics and economy become more important. The northern provinces become more isolated than under Spanish government. Mexican authorities lose control of the northern frontier. Mexicans resort to increased violence when dealing with Apaches. They eventually place bounties on Apaches and hire bounty hunters to bring in Apache scalps. Bounty hunters prey on peaceful rancherias, which are easy targets, more than on hostile Apaches. Some presidios, apparently, poison Apaches. Apaches generally become more hostile and retaliate more frequently against the Mexicans than they did against the Spanish. Revenge  becomes an important driving force of hostilities. The frontier economy declines during these years. Military garrisons decrease in size. Civilian militias become more important, although largely ineffective. Economic support by the central government of the Apaches declines. Mexican communities frequently take hostages to use as advantage against the Apaches. Apaches do the same. Apaches frequently trade goods to one community that they take from another. Political confusion exists on the northern frontier. Mexicans become increasingly worried about a general Apache revolt.
events.source: Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010.

events.title: The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan
events.description: The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan (SDCP) is guiding regional efforts to conserve the best lands and most precious resources for future generations of Pima County residents to enjoy. The Plan combines short-term actions with long-range land-use decisions in Pima County, one of the most biologically diverse counties in the U.S. From cactus-studded deserts to conifer forests, the diverse landscape of Pima County is the home to a million residents from diverse ethnic and cultural backgrounds, and contains a rich diversity of plant and animal life.

events.title: Colossal Cave Mountain Park Expansion
events.description: Pima County‰Ûªs first efforts to conserve Colossal Cave began in 1944, when the County leased almost 500 acres from the State Land Department for purposes of a park.  Using 1986 voter-approved bond funds for park land acquisition, the County began to establish the mountain park to protect the cave in 1989 and a Pima County park was formally established in 1992.  Acquisitions included the historic Posta Quemada Ranch, which is also the site of a 120-year old stagecoach station.  Colossal Cave Mountain Park (CCMP) supports habitat for almost half of the bat species in the State of Arizona, including the endangered Lesser Long-nosed bat.  CCMP also protects large segments of lush riparian vegetation along Agua Verde Creek, a major tributary to Cienega Creek.

events.title: Walden and Other Properties that Contribute to the Reserve
events.description: The properties were acquired because of their basic ecological and habitat values. Walden Property McKenzie Property Poteet Property Amadon and Nunez Properties

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Expansion
events.description: Recognizing the incredible importance of Cienega Creek and its watershed, the Board of Supervisors established the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve in 1986 using voter-approved bond funds for flood prone land.  Spanning 4,000 acres, the Preserve protects 12 miles of the lower reaches of Cienega Creek, which supports native endangered fish species, provides aquifer recharge, and provides important natural flood control protections that lessen impacts to the developed areas in the Tucson Basin.  The Preserve also hosts the historic railroad town of Pantano, along with many archaeological features, including bedrock mortars.

events.title: The acquisition of Bar V Ranch
events.description: Pima County‰Ûªs acquisition of the Bar V Ranch contributes to the conservation of one of the most important wildlife movement corridors in the Cienega Valley.  The 14,400 acre Bar V Ranch is located between the Rincon and Santa Rita Mountains, and adjacent to the County‰Ûªs Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.  The ranch includes a significant portion of Davidson Canyon, an important tributary and water source to Cienega Creek and the Tucson Basin.  Acquisition of the Bar V Ranch preserves a large intact piece of the Empire-Cienega landscape and protects important riparian habitat crucial for several vulnerable species.

events.title: The acquisition of Sands Ranch
events.description: In its entirety, the historic Sands Ranch totals 64,000 acres, spanning east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to the San Pedro River in Cochise County.  With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County acquired the 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch located in the far southeast corner of Pima County.  This acquisition further connects a system of publicly-owned lands from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains, especially when coupled with the County‰Ûªs subsequent acquisition of the adjacent Clyne Ranch.  Not only does it contribute to the health of the Cienega Watershed, but also conserves high quality native grasslands and wildlife movement corridors.

events.title: The acquisition of Empirita Ranch
events.description: The Empirita (little Empire) Ranch actually broke off from the larger Empire Ranch in 1941. In 1991 and 92, the Pima County Flood Control District purchased 360 acres of the Empirita Ranch. In 2001, Pima County‰Ûªs acquisition of the 2,700-acre Empirita property conserved the last remaining portions of the private land that comprised the historic Empirita Ranch.  With assistance from the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County negotiated the purchase of the Empirita property, along with the owner assigning the County its contractual right to withdraw up to 1,600 acre feet of groundwater annually from the Cienega Creek Basin.  The Empirita acquisition expands upon already conserved reserves, including the Coronado National Forest, the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, and the County‰Ûªs Bar V Ranch, Empirita Ranch and Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.

events.title: The acquisition of Clyne Ranch
events.description: The County‰Ûªs acquisition of 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch,located east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, in December 2008, created an interconnected corridor of conserved lands spanning from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains.  With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County then acquired the Clyne Ranch parcels, located adjacent to the County‰Ûªs Sands Ranch and also east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, totaling 880 acres.  In addition, development restrictions were placed on 90 acres maintained by the seller. The ranch is an integral part of this assemblage of publicly-owned lands and further contributes to this corridor through the Cienega Valley.  The Clyne Ranch parcels, like the Sands Ranch, contains high quality native grasslands found in the Sonoita Valley area.

events.description: Vail and partner Carroll Gates buy 1000 (and most likely much more than that) acres of scrip from lands in the Sierra Forest Reserve. In 1899 they exchange scrip for over 2000 acres of lands in Empire Valley and other southern valleys. These sites cover many water sources. Dowell: 115. Also general land office land patent records under Walter Vail.

events.title: A Great Rift Valley forms in southeastern Arizona
events.description: The rift valley is associated with the formation of the Gulf of Mexico. Ocean waters fill the southeastern portion of the valley, ebbing and flowing through the years. Rift valley lakes fill the northwestern portions of the valley, as far north as Tucson. A particularly large lake, perhaps 20 miles wide and 60 miles long existed for a period in this area.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rocks of the Fort Crittenden Formation deposited
events.description: Deposited in intermontane lakes and alluvial fans formed during early laramide deformation. Fossils include: petrified wood, pollen, snails, mussels, fishes (Lepisosteus ,Melvius, Pachyrhizodus ,Palaeolabrus), turtles (Adocus ,Plastomenus ,Helopanoplia , Trionyx sl), a polyglyphonodontine lizard, an alligatoroid and dinosaurs (Tyrannosaur, Allosauroid, Dromaeosaurid, Hadrosaurine , Nasutoceratops (?), Chasmosaur , Ankylosaurine , and Egg Shell).

events.title: Massive volcanic activity from a giant volcano may have ended local life.
events.description: Massive volcanic activity from giant volcanos in the area, at a scale that one must suspect that life was largely eliminated. Upon emptying out its magma chamber, one of the volcanos collapsed in on itself forming a giant caldera in the Mt Fagan area.
events.source: McCord R. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Evidence of early maize agriculture discovered.
events.description: In Cienega Creek alluvial sediments dated stratigraphically to the same period as EE:2:30, Paul Martin and James Schoenwetter discovered pollen evidence of early maize agriculture.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.
events.source (original): Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Excavations at EE:2:30 and Los Ojitos defined Early Agricultural period.
events.description: Bruce Huckell, supported by Anamax and U of Arizona, excavated again at EE:2:30 and at Los Ojitos, 500 meters downstream in Cienega Creek channel. Large numbers of artifacts and pithouses represented early agricultural village settlement occupied year round for perhaps a decade. Work provided basis for defining the Cienega phase of Early Agricultural Period as 800 BC to AD50. Huckell notes the diverse biotic communities, first-class farmland along a gentle flowing perennial stream and a relatively long growing season were highly conducive to maize agriculture in the area.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.
events.source (original): Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Human remains were found along Cienega Creek.
events.description: Bryon Cummings, director of the Arizona State Museum excavated two burials exposed by erosion along Cienega Creek, 3.75 meters below the modern ground surface. Based on this depth, Bryon assigned an ancient date.

events.title: Human settlements and activities during the Archaic period became highly adaptive to area landscape.
events.description: The Archaic prehistory period was marked by patterns of hunting and intensive plant collecting with seasonal mobile camps for thousands of years. Many sites exist in the Cienega Valley attesting to this successful adaptation to changing environments.
events.source: Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001. .

events.title: In Matty Canyon, excavation of a San Pedro stage preceramic site.
events.description: Frank Eddy excavated preceramic site AZ EE:2:30 buried over 5 meters in the alluvium but exposed on the channel floor of Matty Wash. Rich in remains, Eddy termed this a San Pedro phase, Cochise cultural base camp.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.
events.source (original): Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Marsh Station Road site excavations reveal early agricultural practices along Cienega Creek.
events.description: William Self Associates conducted surveys and excavations to support Kinder Morgan's new pipeline from El Paso to Phoenix. WSA partially excavated Marsh Station Rd site, a village with evidence of early agriculture in Cienega Creek. Maize cobs dated to 900 BC and 790 BC. Rich site yield pithouses, 148 features and 40,000 artifacts.
events.source: William Self Associates, Inc. A Modern Pipeline and An Ancient Place . Web page.2015.
events.source (original): William Self Associates, Inc. A Modern Pipeline and An Ancient Place. http://www.williamself.com/Kinder%20Morgan%20-%20EPX%20Cienega%20Creek.pdf

events.title: Paleo-Indian hunters hunted big game in Southern Arizona
events.description: Humans followed big game (megafauna, mammoth, bison, antelope), smaller animals and gathering plants. No Paleo-Indian sites recorded yet but finding these sites may be difficult due to: 1) sites may be deeply buried and occasionally exposed by erosion into old deposits; 2) the material remains are scant and do not include ceramics, house structures, or other features; 3) due to the mobile patterns; 4) material culture was perishable; and 5) sites are ephemeral in nature and the overall site density would have been low given the hunting and gathering patterns. Site potential exist, known mammoth finds.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.
events.source (original): #Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: PaleoIndian Period human settlement continues

events.description: Researchers have investigated protohistoric sites dating to mid-1700s (likely Sobaipuri (but possibly Apache or Tohono O'odham) a roasting pit, house rings of stone. Reported by Kino and Manje occupied Santa Cruz and San Pedro river valleys, maintained agricultural-based villages.

events.title: Stratigraphy and archaeological sites surveyed along Cienega Creek and Matty Canyon.
events.description: Frank Eddy, U of Arizona student, recorded the alluvial stratigraphy and ceramic and preceramic sites along Matty Canyon and Cienega Creek. Eddy applied a unique interdisciplinary approach to archaeological research. He collaborated with a geologist, palynologist and malacologist. Eddy's work demonstrated the rich cultural history spanned more than 3,000 years and that spatial patterning of sites could be tied to changes in the floodplain environment.
events.source (original): Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2. #Eddy FW, Cooley ME, Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona, Tucson, A: University of Arizona Press. 1983. Anthropological Papers No. 43.

events.title: Survey and excavations for proposed Anamax Coronado Nat'l Forest land exchange.
events.description: Arizona State Museum conducted a large scale intensive survey and excavation project to the proposed land exchange between the Coronado National Forest and the Anamax Mining Corporation. Numerous Archaic, Hohokam, and historic sites near Rosemont were identified and excavated greatly expanding archaeologists understanding of the area.
events.source: Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest.. 2001. 15(4):2.
events.source (original): Huckell BB. History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley. Archaeology Southwest. 2001;15(4):2.

events.title: Santa Rita Mountains (143,645 acres) nominated as a traditional cultural property
events.description: Nomination of Ce:wi Duag ('Long Mountain') as a Tohono O'odham Traditional Cultural Property. Nomination notes that others (all O'Odham, Apache, Zuni, Hopi, Pascua Yaqui along with Hispanic communities, local ranchers and residents) have deep ties and values for the Santa Rita mountains. Evidence includes historic and current uses for economic and religious uses and 7,000 years of archaeological remains.
events.source: Griset S, W Gillesie, M Farrell.. National Register of Historic Places: Ce:wi Duag ("Long Mountain" in O'odham). National Registration Form: SWCA Environmental Consultants, U.S. Forest Service, and Trans-Sierran Archaeological Research. Dec. 10, 2012.

events.title: Central Arizona Project authorized
events.description: After 22 years of advocacy by the Central Arizona Project Association, President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the bill authorizing funds for the construction of the Central Arizona Project aqueduct. The Department of the Interior and the Bureau of Reclamation are assigned to fund and construct the project.

events.title: Central Arizona Project water confirmed in groundwater reclamation wells
events.description: Isotopic analysis of groundwater withdrawn from CAVSARP, SAVSARP, and Pima Mine Road recharge facilities. Colorado River water is confirmed to beåÊreaching the aquifers beneath the recharge facilities. NotåÊall wells sampled near the facilities show the presence of CAP water, indicating the influence of subsurface hydrology on CAP water distribution in aquifers.
